entry.title: The Hidden Dangers of Public Wi-Fi
entry.summary: Public Wi-Fi, which has long since become the norm, poses threats to not only individual users but also businesses. With the rise of remote work, people can now work from virtually anywhere: a cafe close to home, a hotel in a different city, or even while waiting for a plane at the airport. Next, let's explore the risks of connecting to public Wi-Fi, both for you personally and for businesses.

entry.title: New "Whiffy Recon" Malware Triangulates Infected Device Location via Wi-Fi Every Minute
entry.summary: The SmokeLoader malware is being used to deliver a new Wi-Fi scanning malware strain called Whiffy Recon on compromised Windows machines. "The new malware strain has only one operation. Every 60 seconds it triangulates the infected systems' positions by scanning nearby Wi-Fi access points as a data point for Google's geolocation API," Secureworks Counter Threat Unit (CTU) said in a statement

entry.title: WinRAR Security Flaw Exploited in Zero-Day Attacks to Target Traders
entry.summary: A recently patched security flaw in the popular WinRAR archiving software has been exploited as a zero-day since April 2023, new findings from Group-IB reveal. The vulnerability, cataloged as CVE-2023-38831, allows threat actors to spoof file extensions, thereby making it possible to launch malicious scripts contained within an archive that masquerades as seemingly innocuous image or text files.

entry.summary: NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg told CNN on June 1 that he does not “foresee that because what NATO allies and NATO is doing is to provide support to Ukraine to uphold the right for self-defense, and this is a right which is enshrined in the UN treaty.” The post Stoltenberg: Russia unlikely to retaliate after US provision of advanced weapons to Ukraine. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

entry.title: CNN: UK to send Ukraine long-range rocket systems.
entry.summary: The U.K. will send multiple-launch rocket systems, or M270 launchers, to Ukraine, U.K. Defense Secretary Ben Wallace said on June 1. M270 launchers can hit targets up to 80 kilometers away, giving “a significant boost in capability for the Ukrainian forces,” according to a statement from the U.K. Foreign Office. entry.title: Reuters: Civilians take shelter in chemical plant as Russia shells Sievierodonetsk.
entry.summary: Luhansk Oblast Governor Serhiy Haidai said authorities fear the Azot chemical plant may still contain dangerous materials. However, he said the situation will not become the “second Azovstal.” The post Reuters: Civilians take shelter in chemical plant as Russia shells Sievierodonetsk. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

entry.title: Reuters: US intends to sell Ukraine armed drones in coming days.
entry.summary: The U.S. plans to sell Ukraine four long-endurance MQ-1C Gray Eagle drones, which can be armed with up to eight Hellfire missiles, undisclosed sources told Reuters. While the sale could still be blocked by Congress, it is significant because it would provide Ukraine with an advanced reusable U.S. system able to […] The post Reuters: US intends to sell Ukraine armed drones in coming days. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

entry.title: Poland to sell Ukraine additional 60 KRAB self-propelled howitzers.
entry.summary: Polish media outlet Dziennik reported that these weapons will be delivered in the next few months. In May, Poland sent 18 KRAB self-propelled howitzers to Ukraine. The post Poland to sell Ukraine additional 60 KRAB self-propelled howitzers. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

entry.title: Lviv Oblast Governor: Russian missile strike injures 5 people.
entry.summary: Maksym Kozytsky said that those injured by the cruise missile strike on Lviv Oblast’s Stryisky District on June 1 are not in critical condition. entry.title: Washington Post: US defends decision to provide Ukraine with HIMARS.
entry.summary: U.S. Under Secretary of Defense for Policy Colin Kahl dismissed criticism that the delayed provision of M142 High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems to Ukraine comes too late, saying they will “arrive in a time frame that’s relevant.” The satellite-guided weapons are the most advanced arms sent to Ukraine by the U.S. […] The post Washington Post: US defends decision to provide Ukraine with HIMARS. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

entry.title: Ukrainian troops repel 13 Russian attacks, destroy military equipment.
entry.summary: Operational Command “East” reports that Ukraine’s forces have repelled 13 Russian attacks in the east of the country. Russia has reportedly lost 20 units of military equipment, including two tanks, six artillery pieces, eight armored combat vehicles and four other vehicles. Additionally, Ukraine’s Air Force downed seven Russian “Orlan-10” UAVs. The post Ukrainian troops repel 13 Russian attacks, destroy military equipment. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

entry.title: EU imposes partial oil embargo but keeps funding Putin’s war through gas payments
entry.summary: The European Union on May 31 finally agreed on a partial embargo on Russian oil after months of delays and disagreements. entry.title: Kyiv City Prosecutor’s Office investigates Kryukiv Railway Car Building Works over alleged embezzlement to a Russian entity.
entry.summary: The investigation alleges the plant purchased parts for car construction from Russian companies at inflated prices when it could have bought the same parts at a lower price from Ukraine. entry.summary: Gazprom left the London Stock Exchange following the Russian government’s demand that Russian companies quit Western stock markets. The post Gazprom leaves London Stock Exchange. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

entry.summary: The missile attack occurred on May 31, and damaged a school and at least seven residential buildings, according to Pavlo Kyrylenko, the governor of Donetsk Oblast. entry.title: Verkhovna Rada dismisses ombudsman Denisova.
entry.summary: 234 lawmakers voted to dismiss Lyudmyla Denisova. Earlier, Ukrainian journalists and activists have expressed concerns over Denisova’s reports of rapes by Russian soldiers, that were sometimes seen as insensitive or disrespectful towards survivors. entry.summary: Karl Nehammer claimed that it would be much more difficult to replace Russian gas than Russian oil. entry.title: General Staff: One more Russian offensive towards Sloviansk fails.
entry.summary: Ukraine’s General Staff said that Russian troops had unsuccessfully tried to storm the village of Dovhenke near Sloviansk, Donetsk Oblast. Russian troops are also trying to storm Zolote, Komyshuvakha, Nyrkove, Berestove, Pokrovske and Dolomitne near Bakhmut in Donetsk Oblast, the General Staff said. entry.title: Ukrainian court jails 2 Russian soldiers charged with war crimes.
entry.summary: The court sentenced the two Russians, Alexander Bobykin and Alexander Ivanov, to 11.5 years in prison for shelling residential areas in Kharkiv Oblast. The post Ukrainian court jails 2 Russian soldiers charged with war crimes. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

entry.title: German defense committee chief urges Scholz to unblock supplies of armored vehicles to Ukraine.
entry.summary: Marie-Agnes Strack-Zimmermann, head of the German parliament’s defense committee, has called on German Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s office to deliver 50 Marder infantry fighting vehicles to Ukraine as soon as possible. entry.summary: The ministry said that the strategy of massing forces and fires in a relatively small area had enabled Russian troops to achieve local successes. In contrast, during the first month of the large-scale invasion, Russia suffered military setbacks after scattering its forces over a huge area. entry.summary: The figures are expected to be higher since they do not include child casualties in the areas where hostilities are ongoing and in the occupied areas, the Prosecutor General’s Office said. entry.title: US rejects Russia’s offer to unblock Ukrainian ports in exchange for lifting sanctions.
entry.summary: U.S. Department of State spokesman Ned Price called Russia’s suggestion to unblock Ukrainian ports in exchange for lifting sanctions “empty promises.” “The quickest solution to rising raw material prices and rising food prices around the world is to end the Russians’ brutal war,” Price said. entry.title: World Bank President: Russia’s war in Ukraine could trigger global recession.
entry.summary: David Malpass said on May 25 that Europe, China, and the U.S. were seeing slower growth. Meanwhile, shortfalls in fertilizer, food stocks, and energy supplies hit developing countries. entry.title: Media: NATO members informally agree not to supply Ukraine with aircraft and tanks
entry.summary: Citing its sources in NATO, the German Press Agency reported that alliance members have informally agreed not to supply the weapons to Ukraine, fearing Russia could see the delivery of Western tanks and combat aircraft as entering the war and take retaliatory measures, German newspaper Die Zeit reported. entry.summary: The company said in a statement that “due to operational challenges in Russia, Nike has made the decision not to renew or enter into any new business commitments,” Russian business daily Vedomosti reported. entry.summary: “For the bravery of all our people who are not inferior to Russia and continue to defend our state,” President Zelensky said during his nightly address. entry.title: Zelensky: ‘Russia advancing aggressively in east, we need weapons’
entry.summary: In his nightly address, President Zelensky said that while Ukraine’s Armed Forces are resisting Russia’s offensives in the east, in some places Russia outnumbers Ukraine in troops and equipment. “We still need the help of partners, especially weapons for Ukraine. entry.title: Despite constant heavy shelling, Sievierodonetsk still accessible
entry.summary: Oleksandr Striuk, head of the Sievierodonetsk city military administration, said despite Russia’s constant attacks, the city is not besieged and has enough Ukrainian troops to hold back Russian forces.
